title.value: Towards Continual Reinforcement Learning: A Review and Perspectives
title.justification: The title clearly indicates the focus of the paper on continual reinforcement learning, providing a review and perspectives on the subject.
title.quote: Towards Continual Reinforcement Learning: A Review and Perspectives

extractions.description: This paper provides a comprehensive review of continual reinforcement learning (RL), including different formulations and approaches, a taxonomy of continual RL methods, evaluation benchmarks, and their connections to neuroscience. It outlines the key challenges and areas for future research in the domain of continual RL.

type.justification: The paper primarily discusses various theoretical frameworks, taxonomies, and perspectives on continual RL, rather than conducting experiments or empirical analyses of new methods.
type.quote: In this article, we aim to provide a literature review of different formulations and approaches to continual reinforcement learning (RL), also known as lifelong or non-stationary RL.

name.justification: The paper focuses on reinforcement learning, specifically continual reinforcement learning, as indicated by the discussions on RL paradigms, formulations, and approaches.
name.quote: Recent advances in deep RL have demonstrated superhuman performance by artificially intelligent (AI) agents on a variety of impressive tasks.

name.justification: The paper is centered around continual learning, particularly continual reinforcement learning, discussing its challenges and methodologies.
name.quote: While still in its early days, the study of continual RL has the promise to develop better incremental reinforcement learners that can function in increasingly realistic applications where non-stationarity plays a vital role.

name.justification: The paper explores the connection between continual RL and neuroscience, suggesting that insights from neuroscience could inform better RL models.
name.quote: Finally, we highlight open problems and challenges in bridging the gap between the current state of continual RL and findings in neuroscience.
